com.kuka.sensitivity

Class LBR

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.kuka.geometry.SpatialObject
      • com.kuka.geometry.SerialKinematics
        • com.kuka.device.RoboticArm
          • com.kuka.sensitivity.LBR
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.kuka.capabilities.ICapabilityContainer, com.kuka.geometry.IRobotFlange

    public class LBR
extends com.kuka.device.RoboticArm
    An LBR represents the KUKA lightweight robot (LWR).

    LBR has torque sensors in each joint and has the possibility to determine the external force on its defaultMotionFrame. This force is available via the LBRÂ´s force sensors. It is also possible to use impedance control modes with this robot.

    This type can be instantiated in applications and background tasks via dependency injection, using @Inject, @Named etc.
    The @Named annotation can be used to differentiate between different objects of the same type like process data.
    More detailed information including code examples can be found in the documentation of the base class of the application or background task.

      • getExternalForceTorque

        public com.kuka.device.ForceData getExternalForceTorque(com.kuka.geometry.Frame measureFrame)
        Gets the external force measured by the robot at the position and in the orientation of the specified measure frame.

        Please note:

        • Avoid singular robot positions. Due to mathematical restrictions not every element of the measured force/ torque vector will be correct in these positions.
        • The sensor value is only an estimation of the force. The returned data object allows to query the validity of the measured values.
          (See ForceData.isForceValid(double) and ForceData.isTorqueValid(double))
        Parameters:
        measureFrame - The frame where the measurement will take place. This frame must be statically attached to a device that can measure forces (such as an LBR). If an orientationFrame is given, the orientation of the frame is not important.
        Returns:
        The external force measured by the robot at the specified measure frame.

      • getExternalForceTorque

        public com.kuka.device.ForceData getExternalForceTorque(com.kuka.geometry.Frame measureFrame,
                                                        com.kuka.geometry.Frame orientationFrame)
        Gets the external force measured by the robot at the position and in the orientation of the specified frames.

        Please note:

        • Avoid singular robot positions. Due to mathematical restrictions not every element of the measured force/ torque vector will be correct in these positions.
        • The sensor value is only an estimation of the force. The returned data object allows to query the validity of the measured values.
          (See ForceData.isForceValid(double) and ForceData.isTorqueValid(double))
        Parameters:
        measureFrame - The frame where the measurement will take place. This frame must be statically attached to a device that can measure forces (such as an LBR).
        orientationFrame - Optional frame (may be null) that overrides the orientation of the measureFrame. The translation of the orientationFrame has no influence on the measurement. Use this frame if you want to specify the orientation of the measured force and torque relative to the world coordinate system, for example if you want the coordinate axes orientation for the measurement to have the same orientation like the coordinate system of a work piece.
        Returns:
        The external force measured by the robot regarding the specified measurement frame and orientation.

      • getTorqueSensorLimits

        public double[] getTorqueSensorLimits()
        Gets the torque sensor Limits.
        Returns:
        Array of Values with the nominal Limit of robot axis. May be null if not supported.

      • checkTorqueSensor

        public boolean checkTorqueSensor(com.kuka.device.common.JointEnum joint)
        Checks if the torque sensor of the given axis works properly.
        Parameters:
        joint - The index of the axis.
        Returns:
        True if the torque sensor works properly, false otherwise.
